instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.CPU_VR_EN: What is CPU_VR_EN? CPU_VR_EN is an enable signal for CPU VCORE that is present when it is high. Signals with EN on the end enable whatever came before the EN if the signal is high. Signals with EN on the end enable whatever came before the EN if the signal is high. ALL_SYS_PWRGD, PM_RSMRST_L, PM_SLP_SUS_L, and PM_SLP_S3_L are necessary prerequisites for CPU_VR_EN to be present. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> enters S0 state but has no CPU vcore
threads.message: This board has all voltages but has 0V on CPU vcore. No cycling. Just stays at 0. Vcore measures 12Ω to ground. <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> is getting 5V and 8.6V. Fan does not spin up. Has 5V though. I originally cleaned up an issue with <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> to get it to go into S0. I attached pre-ultrasonic-cleaning pictures. Not sure where to go next with this.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> enters S0 state but has no CPU vcore
threads.message: Assuming you removed JTAG? Check resistance between pin 2 of PPBUS fuse and Pin 2 of L7310 before continuing to make sure PPBUS did not short to VCore.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> enters S0 state but has no CPU vcore
threads.message: No, I didn't remove JTAG. I know it's gospel to pull that thing but I've never had it help and I like having it there in case I need to program the BIOS chip. Regardless, I went ahead and pulled it just now. No change. No short between PPBUS and L7310.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> enters S0 state but has no CPU vcore
threads.message:
If has 8.6V, 5V and even other voltages, there is no short to VCORE for sure...

Recheck to see if catch at least a pulse on VCORE.
Do you get 24MHz at Y1915?
Check SPI termination resistors and traces around <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>/01.
<SIGNAL>CPU_VR_EN</SIGNAL> tries to appear?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> enters S0 state but has no CPU vcore
threads.message: Remove the JTAG at All times if it’s corroded. I’d say check what 2informaticos said for sure

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> enters S0 state but has no CPU vcore
threads.message: Went back to the area of most damage and replaced <RESISTOR>R8151</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R8152</RESISTOR>. They both measured fine but looked bad and the voltage divider wasn't happening. All good after that. Thanks for the help.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> enters S0 state but has no CPU vcore
